Research article High-throughput screening of single-atom catalysts on 1 T-TMD for highly active and selective CO2 reduction reaction: Computational and machine learning insights Shen Xi Writing – original draft Investigation Formal analysis Data curation a Peng Zhao Validation Supervision a Cheng He Writing – review & editing Validation Supervision b ⁎ Wenxue Zhang Validation Supervision a ⁎ a School of Materials Science and Engineering, Chang’an University, Xi’an 710064, China School of Materials Science and Engineering Chang’an University Xi’an 710064 China School of Materials Science and Engineering, Chang’an University, Xi’an 710064, China b State Key Laboratory for Mechanical Behavior of Materials, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an 710049, China State Key Laboratory for Mechanical Behavior of Materials School of Materials Science and Engineering Xi’an Jiaotong University Xi’an 710049 China State Key Laboratory for Mechanical Behavior of Materials, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an 710049, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The study of transition metals and various possible surface compositions has sparked great interest in low-cost materials, which exhibit high activity and selectivity in catalysis. While various single-atom catalysts loaded on transition metal dichalcogenide (TMD) substrates with excellent CO2 reduction performance have been identified, the relationship between catalytic activity and the intrinsic properties of TMD single-atom catalysts remains unclear. Hence, a high-throughput first-principle computational approach is proposed to screen 24 transition metals anchored on 8 TMD monolayers to determine their catalytic activity in CO2RR. The results show that Fe@CoS2, Pt@TiTe2 and Co@CoS2 exhibit exceptional performances with low CO2RR limiting-potentials of −0.045 eV, 0.75 eV, and 0.54 eV, respectively, showcasing selective pathways towards formic acid (HCOOH), methane (CH4), and methanol (CH3OH). Employing the Sure Independence Screening and Sparsifying Operator method(SISSO), key descriptors linking the performance of single-atom catalysts with their intrinsic features are identified, providing insights for the discovery of superior CO2RR catalysts. Moreover, it was observed that a feature of the anchored single atom, the difference between covalent radius and atomic radius (CR-R), is associated with multiple crucial reaction steps, exhibiting a strong linear relationship with the charge transfer of *COOH. This work not only identifies promising CO2RR catalysts but also establishes a predictive framework for screening catalysts based on their intrinsic properties, paving the way for future advancements in CO2 reduction research. Keywords Single atom catalysis CO2 reduction reaction Density functional theory High-throughput screening Prediction expression Selection strategy Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The extensive combustion of fossil fuels and industrial processes generates greenhouse gases, contributing to accelerated global warming and significant alterations in Earth's climate [1–5]. Carbon dioxide (CO2), being a major greenhouse gas, offers a promising avenue for addressing environmental and pollution issues by electrochemically reducing and converting it into valuable industrial products [6,7]. Over the past few decades, numerous strategies have been proposed and developed to capture and convert CO2, aiming to reduce its concentration in the atmosphere [8–11]. However, CO2 molecules exhibit remarkable stability, with a bond energy of 750 kJ/mol for the CO bond, and the reaction pathways and mechanisms are intricate [12]. Consequently, the design of highly efficient catalysts for CO2 reduction reactions (CO2RR) remains a forefront challenge. Given the considerable room for improvement in realizing commercial-scale CO2RR products, the field of catalyst development remains a vibrant topic. The pursuit of advanced CO2RR electrocatalysts with high catalytic activity, selectivity and cost-effectiveness continues to be a pressing challenge. To achieve this goal, several aspects need to be considered and optimized. Firstly, the active sites of the catalysts are crucial for their catalytic activity. Secondly, a deep understanding of the reaction mechanism of CO2RR can help in designing more efficient catalysts. DuanMu et al. investigated the carbon deposition process on the copper surface during CO2RR, identifying that carbon deposition predominantly occurs in the methane formation pathway, where *CO is converted to *C via the *COH intermediate, subsequently desorbing to form deposited carbon [13]. Niu et al. developed a La2CuO4 perovskite oxide-derived Cu catalyst for the electrochemical conversion of CO2 into C2 + products in a neutral environment. They found that by enhancing the adsorption of key CO intermediates, the CC coupling steps for C2 + product formation were promoted [14]. By studying the reaction path, intermediates, and active species, a better understanding of the reaction process can be achieved, allowing for targeted optimization of the catalysts. Thirdly, product selectivity is also important in CO2RR reactions. Many studies have focused on the mechanism of the CO2RR reaction and attempted to summarize patterns. Hori et al. investigated the CO2RR products when different pure metals were used as electrodes, classifying catalytic materials into four categories based on the main products: First category, Cd In Sn Hg Tl Pb, primarily produces HCOOH; Second category, Ag Au Zn, primarily produces CO; Third category, Ni, Fe Pt Ti, primarily produces H2; Fourth category, Cu, primarily produces hydrocarbons [15]. Zhang et al. studied the CO2RR catalytic performance of bimetallic 2D c-MOFs, providing two descriptors to regulate catalytic performance and designing favorable M1Pc-M2-O catalysts [16]. Two-dimensional materials exhibit exceptional physical and mechanical characteristics. The surface of perfect two-dimensional materials is typically inert, but introducing defects on the surface can alter their intrinsic physical properties and enhance chemical reactivity [17]. Among these, Single Atom Catalysts (SACs), as a novel class of electrocatalysts, feature active sites composed of individual atoms or a minimal number of atoms, making them one of the most promising catalysts [18]. Unlike traditional catalysts, which often consist of nanoparticles composed of multiple metal atoms, SACs disperse metal atoms as single entities on a solid support [19]. SACs typically exhibit outstanding catalytic activity, as each metal atom can be fully utilized, and their active sites are easily accessible [20]. Moreover, the highly dispersed metal atoms in SACs provide more precise reaction sites, enhancing catalytic selectivity and reducing side reactions. The use of fewer metal atoms in SACs significantly reduces the demand for rare or expensive metals, contributing to more efficient resource utilization [21]. Due to the ease of characterization and understanding of the catalytic mechanism at individual atomic sites, SACs are conducive to in-depth studies of catalytic mechanisms. While many studies focus on the impact of anchoring single atoms on the modification of SAC catalytic performance, there is limited research considering the influence of substrate properties on SAC catalytic performance. To systematically study the impact of substrates on catalytic performance, a series of structurally similar but different two-dimensional materials are needed as the substrates for SACs. This allows for the investigation of how a specific property of the substrate influences the overall catalytic performance of SACs. Transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), a vital branch of the two-dimensional materials family, possess high surface area, strong interaction with light fields, and high charge carrier mobility, making them ideal substrates for loading single-atom catalysts [22,23]. Typically, TMD materials appear in the form of MX2, where M is the central transition metal atom, and X represents chalcogen atoms (S, Se or Te) [24]. Based on the coordination environment of metal atoms, the peeled two-dimensional TMD materials can be classified into different phases (2H, 1 T, 1 T’), each with unique structures and electronic properties [25–27]. These phases range from semiconductors (such as MoS2, TiS2) to semimetals (such as WTe2, TiSe2), metals (such as NbS2, VSe2), and even superconductors (such as NbSe2, TaS2) [27–30]. Jaberi et al. reported that the 1 T phase of CoS2 exhibits lower electron transfer resistance, suggesting potentially better electrocatalytic characteristics compared to the 2H phase [31]. The 1 T phase of VTe2 has also been experimentally synthesized and demonstrated to possess high conductivity and strong electron correlation [32,33]. Nevertheless, the saturated coordination atoms on the TMD substrate fundamentally limit the available active sites for electrocatalytic reactions. Therefore, the strategy of employing TMD-supported transition metal atoms to create SACs holds significant promise. In recent years, numerous advanced TMD-loaded single-atom electrocatalysts have been designed, including catalysts with excellent CO2 reduction performance. For instance, Zhang et al. anchored seven transition metal atoms on the 2H phase of WTe2, discovering that Ni@WTe2 exhibited optimal catalytic performance and suppressed competing reactions [34]. Pu et al. investigated the doped non-noble metal SAC on vacancy-defective TMDs, discovering that Sc and Ti single atoms exhibited better catalytic performance and selectivity in electrochemical CO2RR compared to noble metal single atoms[35]. Utilizing TMD materials as the substrate for SACs allows for the easy construction of many structurally similar but distinct TM@TMD catalysts. It is worth mentioning that diatomic catalysts (DACs) anchored on TMDs are also promising CO2RR catalysts. Insights gained from SAC studies can provide valuable guidance for the screening of DACs. Therefore, TMD-supported single-atom catalysts are well-suited for investigating the intrinsic mechanisms of CO2RR reactions. Artificial intelligence models are becoming increasingly popular in the discovery of new materials. They can analyze large volumes of experimental or computational data to uncover potential feature relationships and offer new insights. Many studies have attempted to predict material performance based on intrinsic properties. Sun et al. used an energy-based first-principles machine learning method to study trends in CO2RR on single-atom catalysts and revealed unique proportional relationships in hydrogenation steps related to active sites [36]. Among various models, SISSO stands out as an interpretable machine learning method capable of handling vast correlated feature spaces and converging on optimal solutions from feature combinations related to material properties, making it a very promising algorithm. Wu et al. utilized SISSO to analyze the free energies of key steps in the nitrogen reduction reaction on 55 catalysts, deriving predictive expressions and corresponding descriptors, and providing insights into selecting suitable catalytic centers [37]. Jiang et al. applied SISSO to study the performance of N-doped graphene-based single-atom catalysts for HER, establishing connections between substrate size and dimension with performance [38]. Thus, we introduced SISSO to analyze and explore the free energy data obtained from our calculations to provide further catalytic insights. Herein, the free energy changes of 192 TM@TMD single-atom catalysts in key steps of the CO2RR are calculated, and three suitable monolayers (Fe@CoS2, Pt@TiTe2 and Co@CoS2) with low limiting potentials for catalyzing CO2RR are identified. Furthermore, the catalytic performances and the relationship with the intrinsic properties of the monolayers were thoroughly investigated and analyzed using SISSO, as shown in Fig. 1 . The results show that Fe@CoS2, Pt@TiTe2 and Co@CoS2 exhibit exceptional performances with low CO2RR limiting-potentials of −0.045 eV, 0.75 eV, and 0.54 eV, respectively, showcasing selective pathways towards formic acid (HCOOH), methane (CH4), and methanol (CH3OH). By summarizing and analyzing the free energy changes of CO2RR on these monolayers, predictive expressions and rules for selecting single atoms anchored on TMD substrates are derived. Hence, for different desired products, the selection of anchored atoms and substrates can refer to following four rules: (1) The arithmetic mean electronegativity of TMD should preferably be high. (2) For HCOOH product, anchored single atoms, excluding Fe, Co, Ni, Re, Os, Ir, and Pt, should be chosen with higher ionization energy. (3) For CH4 product, anchored single atoms should be primarily selected from Fe, Co, Ni, Re, Os, Ir, and Pt. Additionally, it is preferable to opt for transition metals with a larger difference between covalent radius and atomic radius (CR-R) and higher ionization energy. (4) For CH3OH product, TM@TMD catalysts with low overpotentials are challenging to obtain. Therefore, by selecting Co and Hg as anchoring single atoms and TMD with electron affinity similar to anchoring single atoms as the substrate, it is possible to screen catalysts with methanol selectivity. 2 Methods This study was conducted using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [39,40]. The projector-augmented wave (PAW) method was employed to describe the interactions between ions and electrons, while the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) functional was used to handle relevant exchange–correlation interactions [41]. The cutoff energy was set to 400 eV, and a Monkhorst-Pack scheme with a 4 × 4 × 1 k-point grid was employed for Brillouin zone sampling [42]. The DFT-D3 method was utilized to account for intermolecular interactions [43,44]. For TM@TMD structures, a vacuum layer of 15 Å was included to mitigate interactions between layers. The Gibbs free energy (G) was determined using the formula: G = E + E zero - T S , where G represents the Gibbs free energy, E is the total energy, E zero is the zero-point energy, T is the temperature, and S is the entropy [45]. The Sure Independence Screening and Sparsifying Operator (SISSO) software package was employed to analyze the complex relationship between catalyst selectivity and intrinsic properties along various pathways [46,47]. The random forest regression module in scikit-learn library was utilized to assess the importance of various intrinsic properties in influencing the performance [48]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure, Stability, and electronic properties In this study, eight 1 T-phase transition metal dichalcogenide (TMD) materials (TMD = CoS2, CoSe2, CoTe2, MnSe2, TiS2, TiSe2, TiTe2 and VTe2) are selected as two-dimensional material substrates for constructing single-atom catalysts. A 2 × 2 supercell is established. The optimized unit cell lattice parameters of the TMD materials range from 3.15 Å to 3.69 Å, consistent with previous studies on TMD materials [24,31,49–54]. Additionally, molecular dynamics simulations are conducted at 298 K for 1000 ps, revealing no structural deformations, as illustrated in Fig. S1. Metal atom top sites (M−sites) and chalcogen atom top sites (S-sites) are considered as potential anchoring points for transition metal (TM) atoms, as shown in Fig. 2 . Single transition metal atoms are anchored on intact TMD surfaces rather than surfaces with vacancies, as the vacancy formation energies in most TMD materials are relatively higher, rendering it thermodynamically unfavorable. Moreover, not all the radii of transition metal atoms considered in this study can match the radii of vacancies, and introducing excessively large atoms into vacancies may cause significant structural deformations, compromising structural stability. Subsequently, 24 transition metal elements from the 4th to 6th periods, excluding rare earth elements (TM = Sc, Ti, V, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Y, Zr, Nb, Mo, Tc, Ru, Pd, Ag, Cd, Hf, Ta, W, Re, Os, Ir and Pt) are anchored on the aforementioned eight TMD substrates, resulting in a total of 192 TM@TMD single-atom catalysts. To verify the stabilities of TM@TMD monolayers, the electrochemical stabilities of 192 combinations of transition metals and TMD are evaluated by calculating the formation energies. The formation energy ( E f ) is computed using the formula: E f = ( E TM @ T M D - E TMD - μ TM ) , where E f is the formation energy, μ TM is the chemical potential of M, and E TM @ T M D , E TMD are the energies of the anchored atom on the substrates, the unanchored substrates, respectively. A negative formation energy indicates that the metal single atom is more stable fixed on the TMD surface than aggregated. Based on the formation energy and whether the TM@TMD monolayers undergo significant deformation after structural optimization, 54 stable TM@TMD catalysts with negative formation energies are selected from the 192 TM@TMD monolayers. The detailed list of relevant information are provided in Table S1. It can be observed that for most transition metal elements in the sixth period, the structural stabilities of typically TM@TMD monolayers are not satisfactory, possibly due to their excessively large radii. Additionally, TM anchored at the S-site are generally more stable than those anchored at the M−site, likely due to the closer proximity of the anchoring atom to the transition metal atom in the TMD, leading to higher spatial hindrance at the M−site. This phenomenon becomes more apparent with increasing transition metal radius on the TMD substrate, confirming this explanation. In summary, TM anchored at the S-site are more stable configurations, and subsequent calculations are based on TM@TMD doped at the site with the lowest E f . 3.2 CO2RR reaction and free energy calculations on TM@TMD The CO2RR exhibits complexly reaction pathways, and we have considered three reaction pathways: (1) reduction of CO2 to *OCHO, further hydrogenation to HCOOH as the final product; (2) CO2 undergoes reverse water–gas shift (RWGS) to form the intermediate product *CO: CO2 is hydrogenated to form *COOH, *COOH continues to hydrogenate and desorb a water molecule to form *CO. Then, *CO is hydrogenated to form *CHO → *CH2O → *CH3O, and finally, hydrogenation leads to CH3OH; (3) similar to the CH3OH pathway, CO2 undergoes RWGS to form *CO, *CO is hydrogenated to form *CHO → *CH2O → *OCH3. Subsequently, hydrogenation leads to CH4 desorption, leaving behind an *O atom on TM@TMD, and the remaining *O atom undergoes two more hydrogenation steps to desorb as a water molecule, as shown in Fig. 3 . Furthermore, upon completing the RWGS process, aside from the formation of *CHO as outlined in the aforementioned pathways, *CO can desorb directly or undergo hydrogenation to generate *COH, subsequently leading to the production of CH4 and other byproducts. Notably, the calculated free energy changes for *CO desorption and the step of *CO → *COH generally exhibit high values, predominantly exceeding 1.5 eV, hence, these two CO2RR reaction pathways are excluded from consideration in this study. In the calculations, since both the CH4 and CH3OH pathways involve RWGS reactions to form *CO, the free energy changes are first calculated to form *CO, and TM@TMD structures with excessively large free energy changes (ΔG > 1 eV) are screened out before subsequent calculations. The free energy changes for all 54 stable TM@TMD structures on the three reaction pathways are calculated, and the free energy changes for some structures along each pathway are shown in Fig. 3, while the remaining TM@TMD structures' free energy change pathways are provided in Table S4. For *COOH, the adsorption of it on the surfaces of Pt@CoS2, V@CoS2, V@CoSe2, Co@TiTe2, Ni@TiTe2 and Co@VTe2 is unstable. In the cathodic electrochemical reduction of CO2, the first hydrogenation step has three possible competitive reactions, leading to the formation of *OCHO, *COOH and *H, corresponding to the HCOOH pathway, the CH3OH/CH4 pathway, and the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), respectively. To confirm whether the catalyst is an ideal CO2RR catalyst, it is necessary to identify the competitiveness of the three reactions on the catalyst surface substrates, i.e., ΔG*OCHO and ΔG*COOH should be smaller than ΔG*H. The relationship between ΔG*COOH, ΔG*OCHO, and ΔG*H is shown in Fig. 3d. TM@TMD structures above and below the black dashed lines favor HER and CO2RR, respectively. In the reaction pathway of generating HCOOH, four TM@TMD structures exhibiting low limiting potentials (<1 eV) are identified. Due to the radioactivity of technetium (Tc), it is deemed unsuitable as a catalyst. Additionally, on Co@VTe2 and Ni@VTe2, the thermodynamic desorption barrier for HCOOH is excessively high. Consequently, Te@CoS2 is considered the most favorable catalyst for HCOOH generation. For the pathways yielding CH4, Pt@TiTe2 and Ni@CoS2 with low limiting potentials are identified, with Pt@TiTe2 exhibiting the lowest limiting potential (0.59 eV). In the case of the CH3OH generation pathway, Co@CoS2 with a low limiting potential (0.54 eV) is selected. The computational results indicate that for HCOOH production, the limiting step typically occurs at the *OCHO → *HCOOH transformation. In the case of CH4 production, the limiting potentials usually manifest during the *COOH → *CO and *O → *OH steps. For CH3OH production, the limiting potentials are observed during the CHO → CHOH and *CO → *CHO steps. To demonstrate the selectivity, Nudged Elastic Band (NEB) implemented in VASP was employed to determine the energy barrier of the reaction bifurcation step, as shown in Fig. S8 and S9. The results indicate that in terms of selectivity for *COOH and *OCHO, Fe@CoS2 tends to form *OCHO, while Co@CoS2 and Pt@TiTe2 tends to favor the *COOH pathway. In terms of selectivity between *CHOH and *CH2O, Co@CoS2 tends to favor *CHOH pathway, while Pt tends to favor *CH2O pathway, consistent with previous predictions in free energy. Therefore, in subsequent machine learning predictions of catalysts for CO2RR performance, particular attention is directed towards these five reaction steps. The effective activation of inert CO2 molecules represents a pivotal step in their chemical transformation [55]. Therefore, a thorough analysis of the electronic properties of CO2 adsorption on Fe@CoS2, Pt@TiTe2, and Co@CoS2 has been conducted in this study. As depicted in Fig. 4 a–c, CO2 chemisorbs on Fe@CoS2, and in comparison to linear CO2 molecules (180°), the adsorbed CO2 molecules exhibit a bent configuration with an O-C-O angle of 157°, indicating a higher degree of activation. Conversely, on Pt@TiTe2 and Co@CoS2, which tend to undergo the reverse water–gas shift (RWGS) process, CO2 exhibits physisorption. Fig. 4d–f illustrate the differential charge density of CO2 adsorption on the three substrates. Regardless of the adsorption mode, there is an accumulation of charges between the anchored single atom and the CO2 molecule, while the dispersion of electrons occurs between the anchored single atom and the substrate. This indicates that under the influence of the substrate, the electrons on the anchored single atom become delocalized, interacting with CO2. Furthermore, calculations were performed on the projected density of states (PDOS) and crystal orbital Hamiltonian populations (COHP) between CO2 and Fe@CoS2, as shown in Fig. S2. The d orbitals of the anchored single atom exhibit noticeable coupling with the C atom. After adsorption onto Fe@CoS2, the anti-bonding portion of the CO bond is partially filled, suggesting electron transfer from the metal to the anti-bonding orbital of CO2, simultaneously accepting the lone pair of electrons from CO2. The ultimate outcome is the accumulation of charge on CO2, consequently weakening the CO bond, facilitating further protonation to *OCHO. 3.3 Machine learning of selectivity In order to predict catalyst performance using intrinsic material data, SISSO was employed to obtain the expressions for selectivity and the free energy changes of key reaction steps, to predict potential catalysts. The intrinsic features used in the SISSO analysis include covalent radius ( CR ), radius ( R ), Pauling electronegativity ( χ ) ionization energies ( I n , n = 1, 2, 3), and electron affinity ( EA ) for the transition metal (TM) atoms, non-metal atoms, and anchored single atoms in the TMD materials. Additionally, features such as the arithmetic mean electronegativity ( M χ ) and geometric mean electronegativity ( G χ ) of the TMD materials, as well as the d orbital electron count ( D ) for both the transition metal atoms and anchored single atoms, totaling 25 features. By fitting the free energy changes of key reaction steps with intrinsic features, we can derive descriptors to predict catalytic activity and selectivity without further calculations. To ensure the reliability and accuracy of our predictive models and to prevent overfitting, we implemented a 10-fold cross-validation approach. The mean squared error (MSE) values obtained for the SISSO fitting of the Gibbs free energy changes are as follows: Δ G ∗ H 0.015, Δ G ∗ H C O O H 0.203, Δ G ∗ C O 0.245, Δ G ∗ O H 0.140, Δ G CHO 0.197, Δ G ∗ C H O H 0.274. Additionally, we attempted to fit the formation energies of SACs, with the results presented in Fig. S10. Another criterion for selecting catalysts is their selectivity in competition with HER. Therefore, the relationship between the magnitude of ΔG*H on the catalyst surface and the intrinsic data of the materials was also studied. The descriptor obtained is given by the formula: (1) Δ G ∗ H = - 100.498 × M χ EA S ∗ I 1 M ∗ χ S + 0.195 × EA SA + I 1 S R SA ∗ χ SA + 4.725 where R SA , EA SA , χ SA are the atom radius, electron affinity and electronegativity of the anchored single atom, I 1 S , EA S , χ S are the first ionization energies, electron affinity and electronegativity of the chalcogen elements in TMD substrate, I 1 M is the first ionization energies of the metal element in TMD monolayers, and M χ is the arithmetic mean electronegativity of the TMD monolayers respectively. The MSE of the prediction results is 0.0096. Random forest regression analysis indicates a strong correlation between the magnitude of Δ G ∗ H and I 1 S , larger I 1 S corresponds to higher Δ G ∗ H , as shown in Fig. 5 a. This result suggests that to suppress the HER reaction on the catalyst surface, TMD monolayers should be composed of chalcogen elements with high first ionization energies, i.e., S. Here, utilizing the predictive equations provided by SISSO, we predicted Δ G ∗ H values for TM@TMD monolayers, where transition metal atoms from the 4th, 5th and 6th periods were anchored on various TMD monolayers. The resulting predicted hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) activity is presented in the Fig. S3. The prediction results show that TM@TMD monolayers composed of TMDs with S and Se generally exhibit higher free energy changes for the first protonation step of HER. Moreover, the predictive results indicate that for TMD monolayers composed of Re, W, Ta as well as Co and Mn, the supported single-atom catalysts may exhibit lower hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) activity. This observation could provide valuable guidance for investigating catalysts competing with HER, such as catalysts for nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR). Additionally, to predict the selectivity of catalysts for various products, the difference between Δ G ∗ C O O H and Δ G ∗ O C H O was analyzed and predicted using partial intrinsic data of TM@TMD catalysts. The results are as follows. The MSE is 0.074. A positive value for Δ G ∗ C O O H - Δ G ∗ O C H O indicates a preference for the HCOOH pathway, while a negative value suggests a tendency towards the RWGS pathway. Random forest regression analysis reveals that the features influencing selectivity for these two pathways the most are I 2 S A and EA SA , as shown in Fig. 5b. SISSO results indicate that the selectivity in this step is primarily related to the properties of the anchored single atom and the transition metal atom in the TMD monolayers. Various combinations of common transition metals in TMD monolayers with transition metal atoms from the 4th, 5th, and 6th periods were considered and predicted for selectivity using the provided formula, as shown in Fig. 6 a. From the prediction results, it can be observed that the element changes in the anchored transition metals has the greatest impact on the predicted selectivity, aligning with the analysis from the random forest regression. Additionally, according to the predictions, selecting Fe, Co, Ni, as well as Re, Os, Ir, Pt as the anchored single atoms tends to favor the RWGS reaction, while other atoms are more likely to undergo the HCOOH pathway. It can be observed that when using single atoms from lower periods as catalysts, it is challenging to find catalysts with CH3OH selectivity; in the calculation samples, only one combination aligns with CH3OH selectivity. However, according to the SISSO prediction results, Co and Hg as single atoms might exhibit good CH3OH selectivity. 3.4 Machine learning of key reaction steps Next, to predict the catalytic performance of catalysts in various pathways, the relationship between the free energy of key steps and the structural intrinsic data of TM@TMD catalysts was calculated. For HCOOH, the limiting step mainly occurs in the second step, for CH4, it is in the OH and CO steps, and for CH3OH, it is in the CHOH and CHO steps. Therefore, to predict the catalytic performance of CO2RR using intrinsic data of TM@TMD monolayers, the free energy changes of key steps were analyzed with SISSO software, and their relationships with partial intrinsic data of TM@TMD monolayers were obtained. This aims to predict the free energy changes of key steps in CO2RR and identify potential catalysts. For the HCOOH pathway, the fitted formula for Δ G ∗ H C O O H is as follows. (4) Δ G ∗ H C O O H = - 122.5214 ∗ CR S I 3 S A ∗ R SA 3 - 0.1831 ∗ D SA + D M ∗ χ S - G χ + 3.6587 here, R SA , I 3 S A and χ S have been explained above, D SA is the d-orbital electron number of the anchoring atom, D M is the d-orbital electron number of the metal element in the TMD monolayers, CR S is the covalent radius of the chalcogen in the TMD, G χ represents the geometric mean electronegativity of the TMD monolayers, respectively. The MSE is 0.089. Random forest regression results show that G χ and I 3 S A have the greatest importance for Δ G ∗ H C O O H , as shown in Fig. 7 a. From the equation, it is evident that as the geometric mean electronegativity of the substrate increases, Δ G ∗ H C O O H also increases. Here, the DOS for various TM@TMD monolayers, with Ti and Y anchored on CoS2, CoSe2, and CoTe2 substrates during the adsorption of *OCHO, was calculated, as illustrated in Fig. S4. Near the Fermi level, a deeper degree of orbital hybridization corresponds to stronger interactions. It is observed that on substrates with lower electronegativity, stronger coupling occurs between the d-orbitals of the anchoring atom and the p-orbitals of the oxygen atom, corresponding to lower free energy changes in the reaction. Furthermore, it can be inferred that due to the higher strength of interactions between intermediate products and anchored single atom, the protonation reaction of *OCHO on the catalyst is more favorable. In conclusion, to achieve a catalyst with better selectivity towards HCOOH, transition metal atoms other than Fe, Co, Ni, Re, Os, Ir, Pt should be chosen as anchoring atoms to attain lower free energy changes. Additionally, chalcogen elements with lower electronegativity should be selected, and transition metals with higher ionization energy should be used as anchoring atoms. For the two crucial steps in the CH4 pathway, *COOH→*CO and *O→*OH, the computational formulas obtained by SISSO are as follows. (5) Δ G ∗ C O = 0.415 ∗ EA M + I 1 S A CR SA - R SA + 214.372 ∗ EA M D M 3 ∗ D SA - 5.754 (6) Δ G ∗ O H = - 0.01141 ∗ I 2 S A I 1 S + I 3 S A χ SA - 0.01392 ∗ e I 2 M - I 2 S A + 3.282 Here, R SA , CR SA , I 1 S A , I 2 S A , I 3 S A , D SA , EA M , D M and I 1 S have been explained above, I 2 M is the second ionization energies of the transition metal atom in the TMD monolayers. As shown in Fig. 7b and c, the mean squared errors of Δ G ∗ C O and Δ G ∗ O H are 0.016 and 0.053, respectively. Observably, a larger difference between the covalent radius of the anchored single atom and the atomic radius leads to a smaller Δ G ∗ C O . To delve deeper into the underlying mechanism of this process, the Bader charge distribution was computed for the single-atom catalyst adsorbed with *COOH. The system was divided into three components: the *COOH moiety, the anchored single atom, and the substrate. As illustrated in Fig. 7, S5 and S6, in the *COOH, electrons are typically transferred from the substrate to the *COOH moiety, while the anchored single atom experiences electron loss. On the same substrate, there is a robust linear relationship between the difference in covalent radius and atomic radius of the anchored single atom, and the electrons gained or lost. The larger the difference in CR and R, the less electrons the anchored single atom lose. For transition metals with a smaller radius difference, more electrons are preserved, leading to excessively strong interactions with the *COOH moiety, making further protonation challenging. In contrast, for transition metal atoms with a larger radius difference, such as Tc and Ni, the intermediate products exhibit a moderate bonding strength with the transition metal single atom, facilitating the protonation and deprotonation reactions of *COOH and demonstrating favorable Δ G ∗ C O values. Furthermore, the free energy change in the *COOH → *CO step also increases with the rising electron affinity of the metal elements in the TMD monolayer. The elevation in the electron affinity of metal elements in the TMD monolayers results in a competition for electrons on the anchored single atom, weakening its electron cloud, thereby reducing the difficulty of the *COOH → *CO reaction. This analysis substantiates the observed trends in the computational results. For Δ G ∗ O H , random forest regression analysis shows that the features with the greatest impact are the first ionization energy I 1 S of the chalcogen in the TMD monolayer and the third ionization energy I 3 S A of the anchoring single atom. The larger I 1 S and I 3 S A , the smaller the free energy change for this step. In conclusion, to obtain a better CH4 catalyst, anchoring single atoms should preferably be selected from Fe, Co, Ni, Re, Os, Ir, Pt to avoid competition with HCOOH products. Subsequently, to have a smaller limiting potential, anchoring single atoms should be chosen from transition metals with a larger difference between covalent radius and atomic radius and a higher ionization energy. For the two crucial steps in the CH3OH pathway, Δ G CHO and Δ G ∗ C H O H , the computational formulas obtained by SISSO are as follows. As shown in Fig. 7d and S7 the MSE of Δ G CHO and Δ G ∗ C H O H are 0.034 and 0.060, respectively. For the *CHO step, *CO protonation on anchored single atom forms *CHO. Random forest regression analysis shows that the features with the greatest impact on the free energy change are χ M , R SA and R M , as shown in the Fig. 8 . Larger χ M , R SA , and R M correspond to lower Δ G CHO . For Δ G ∗ C H O H , random forest regression analysis shows that the features with the highest impact are EA SA and D M . Analyzing the formula given by machine learning, it is found that similar to *COOH→*CO step, the factor CR SA - R SA also appears in the formula of Δ G ∗ C H O H , possibly indicating inherent similarity between these two protonation steps. Overall, for the CH3OH pathway, a contradictory fact is that few anchoring single atoms exhibit good CH3OH selectivity, and those with good CH3OH selectivity usually have poor RWGS selectivity. Therefore, it is challenging to screen catalysts with both good CH3OH selectivity and low limiting potential in TM@TMD monolayers. Although, according to the previous analysis, Δ G ∗ C O O H - Δ G ∗ O C H O is primarily determined by the properties of the anchored single atom, however, according to Eq. (2), Δ G ∗ C O O H - Δ G ∗ O C H O is also related to the transition metal elements in the TMD monolayer, where smaller I 1 M corresponds to the selectivity for the RWGS pathway. Consequently, it is conceivable to explore TMD monolayers with lower I 1 M and electron affinity values proximate to those of Co or Hg. Anchoring Co and Hg on such a TMD monolayer to construct TM@TMD catalysts may potentially yield enhanced selectivity for CH3OH production. Among them, Hg has the largest value of CR-R, potentially having a lower limiting potential. Additionally, the electronegativity of the constituents in the TMD monolayer should be relatively large. 4 Conclusions In summary, by combining machine learning methods, a high-throughput computations are performed for the electrocatalytic process CO2RR on 192 TM@TMD monolayers to explore the selectivity and catalytic activity mechanism of single atom CO2RR catalysts. Utilizing SISSO, the relationships between the free energy of key reaction steps and the intrinsic properties of TM@TMD are established. Fe@CoS2, Pt@TiTe2, and Co@CoS2 have been selected withlowlimitpotentialsanddifferentselectivityfor HCOOH, CH4, and CH3OH. SISSO analysis provided formulas for predicting the free energy changes of key steps in CO2RR and HER reactions, as well as the selectivity of different products. The results indicate that the increase of the M χ of the TMD monolayer is conducive to the reduction of the HER activity. The selectivity between *COOH and *OCHO is mainly determined by the anchored single atom rather than the TMD substrate. Specifically, when Fe, Co, Ni, Re, Os, Ir, or Pt is used as the anchored atom, the reaction pathway tends to favor the formation of *COOH for the RWGS reaction, while other elements tend to form *OCHO and produce HCOOH. Most TM@TMD structures with RWGS selectivity tend to proceed along the CH4 pathway, making it challenging to achieve selectivity for CH3OH production. Furthermore, an increase in CR-R for the anchored single atom is advantageous for lowering the free energy of reactions along the CH4 and CH3OH pathways. It is hoped that this work will inspire further exploration of advanced two-dimensional materials as efficient electrocatalysts for high-value-added CO2RR products and have guiding significance for the selection of materials in experiments. coredata.dc:description: The study of transition metals and various possible surface compositions has sparked great interest in low-cost materials, which exhibit high activity and selectivity in catalysis. While various single-atom catalysts loaded on transition metal dichalcogenide (TMD) substrates with excellent CO2 reduction performance have been identified, the relationship between catalytic activity and the intrinsic properties of TMD single-atom catalysts remains unclear. Hence, a high-throughput first-principle computational approach is proposed to screen 24 transition metals anchored on 8 TMD monolayers to determine their catalytic activity in CO2RR. The results show that Fe@CoS2, Pt@TiTe2 and Co@CoS2 exhibit exceptional performances with low CO2RR limiting-potentials of −0.045 eV, 0.75 eV, and 0.54 eV, respectively, showcasing selective pathways towards formic acid (HCOOH), methane (CH4), and methanol (CH3OH). Employing the Sure Independence Screening and Sparsifying Operator method(SISSO), key descriptors linking the performance of single-atom catalysts with their intrinsic features are identified, providing insights for the discovery of superior CO2RR catalysts. Moreover, it was observed that a feature of the anchored single atom, the difference between covalent radius and atomic radius (CR-R), is associated with multiple crucial reaction steps, exhibiting a strong linear relationship with the charge transfer of *COOH. This work not only identifies promising CO2RR catalysts but also establishes a predictive framework for screening catalysts based on their intrinsic properties, paving the way for future advancements in CO2 reduction research.

coredata.dc:title: High-throughput screening of single-atom catalysts on 1 T-TMD for highly active and selective CO2 reduction reaction: Computational and machine learning insights
